title: Why is Tesla increasing price of Full Self-Driving package to $10,000? - Big Tech Companies - Quora

response.answer_text: The price increase reflects Tesla’s confidence that its FSD technology can be delivered soon, and will offer value to customers. As before, the price increase is timed to encourage wavering buyers to purchase the package in the next few days. One also needs to consider rival FSD offerings, in particular Waymo. The company is launching a driverless taxi service in Phoenix, Arizona. The urban area has been mapped to within a few inches so that the lidar (Light or laser radar) mounted on each car’s roof can find its position accurately. The map took a lot of effort to build, and more to keep it updated as things inevitably change. The lidar device is expensive, costing $7,500 to other manufacturers on condition that they do not compete. We don’t know if Waymo is subsidising them as the standard offerings cost $75,000.  This is not something consumers will want on top of their vehicles. Tesla’s $10,000 price competes with Waymo, and we don’t know what the software will cost. It cost billions to develop and test on the roads. Waymo employed drivers to ride in their cars for hundreds of millions of miles. Waymo finally launches an actual public, driverless taxi service https://www.mes-insights.com/lidar-systems-costs-integration-and-major-manufacturers-a-908358/ Tesla’s sensors and electronics are part of every vehicle it sells. The on-board AI is trained to use the same senses as humans, albeit enhanced and more capable. The sensors are cameras (its eyes) looking in every direction, as well as radar which judges distances better than our vision and brain can do.  Autopilot 1.0 was trained with real data returned by the million Teslas on the road. Researchers asked the fleet to find instances of errors in the algorithm as they were discovered and send them back to help train the network. Testing was done in customer’s cars by comparing the AI’s decision with that of the driver. It did not matter if the vehicle was on Autopilot at the time. Altogether Tesla gathered information about billions of miles of real-world driving. Autopilot reached a plateau (or local maximum in AI jargon) and stopped improving. Tesla’s engineers used their experience to rewrite Autopilot 2.0, which is now in the hands of beta-testers. Tesla is adding a new '4D' radar with twice the range for self-driving - Electrek  First look at Tesla's Beta FSD Shows Surprising Poise The videos linked in this article shows test drivers’ reactions to the behaviour of the car. “You didn’t do that!? You didn’t do that!?” “I didn’t do that! I didn’t do that!” Tesla does not need an accurate map for self-driving; it can drive on roads it never saw before. You get that for your $10k.
